articles.headline: Chicago Protests Mostly Peaceful After Video of Police Shooting Is Released
articles.snippet: Murder charges were filed against a white police officer in the 2014 death of a black teenager, who was shot 16 times.
articles.abstract: Murder charges were filed against a white police officer in the 2014 death of a black teenager, who was shot 16 times.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Demonstrators took to the streets of this city’s downtown in tense but largely peaceful protests after the release of video on Tuesday showing the fatal shooting of a black teenager by a white Chicago police officer.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Fewer Golfers, but Some Lush Courses Are Coming Back
articles.snippet: The National Golf Foundation says there are four million fewer golfers than a decade ago. Yet at some communities, homes can go for $5 million.
articles.abstract: The National Golf Foundation says there are four million fewer golfers than a decade ago. Yet at some communities, homes can go for $5 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOCA RATON, Fla. — Weeds, crabgrass and fallen palm fronds cover the wildly overgrown greens of what was once the Mizner Trail Golf Club, its decrepit state emblematic of the fate of hundreds of golf courses around the country, many of them derisively known as “rabbit patches” or “goat farms.”

articles.headline: In Renovation of Golf Club, Donald Trump Also Dressed Up History
articles.snippet: Historians say a plaque installed by Mr. Trump at a golf course on the Potomac River commemorates a Civil War event that never happened.
articles.abstract: Historians say a plaque installed by Mr. Trump at a golf course on the Potomac River commemorates a Civil War event that never happened.
articles.lead_paragraph: STERLING, Va. — When Donald J. Trump bought a fixer-upper golf club on Lowes Island here for $13 million in 2009, he poured millions more into reconfiguring its two courses. He angered conservationists by chopping down more than 400 trees to open up views of the Potomac River. And he shocked no one by renaming the club after himself.

articles.headline: YouTube Kids App Faces New Complaints Over Ads for Junk Food
articles.snippet: Consumer advocacy groups say marketing aimed at children has permeated the YouTube app designed specifically for children, and they are asking the government to examine the issue.
articles.abstract: Consumer advocacy groups say marketing aimed at children has permeated the YouTube app designed specifically for children, and they are asking the government to examine the issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Visit YouTube Kids and typically it will not be long before promotions for junk food appear. The advertisements regularly show up in the form of funny contests and animated stories.

articles.headline: Dream of New Kind of Credit Union Is Extinguished by Bureaucracy
articles.snippet: Brewster Kahle’s credit union has faced a barrage of regulatory audits and limitations, leading him to rethink his decision to open it.
articles.abstract: Brewster Kahle’s credit union has faced a barrage of regulatory audits and limitations, leading him to rethink his decision to open it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brewster Kahle didn’t need to start a bank.

articles.headline: Terrorism Response Puts Belgium in a Harsh Light
articles.snippet: As Brussels remains locked down for a fourth day, the failure to stop two brothers flagged as extremists before the Paris carnage has highlighted Belgium’s perennial dysfunctions.
articles.abstract: As Brussels remains locked down for a fourth day, the failure to stop two brothers flagged as extremists before the Paris carnage has highlighted Belgium’s perennial dysfunctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — A month before the Paris terrorist attacks, Mayor Françoise Schepmans of Molenbeek, a Brussels district long notorious as a haven for jihadists, received a list with the names and addresses of more than 80 people suspected as Islamic militants living in her area.

articles.headline: Rare White House Accord With Koch Brothers on Sentencing Frays
articles.snippet: The Justice Department balks on the package because one of the bills, supported by Koch Industries, would make it harder to prosecute polluters and white-collar criminals.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department balks on the package because one of the bills, supported by Koch Industries, would make it harder to prosecute polluters and white-collar criminals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than a year, a rare coalition of liberal groups and libertarian-minded conservatives has joined the Obama administration in pushing for the most significant liberalization of America’s criminal justice laws since the beginning of the drug war. That effort has had perhaps no ally more important than Koch Industries, the conglomerate owned by a pair of brothers who are well-known conservative billionaires.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: U.A.W. Contracts Change Math for Detroit Automakers
articles.snippet: Deals to address a two-tier wage structure will add to the pressure to maintain earnings and could move less-profitable production to Mexico.
articles.abstract: Deals to address a two-tier wage structure will add to the pressure to maintain earnings and could move less-profitable production to Mexico.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — When union contracts were finally ratified at Ford Motor and General Motors last week, a new era began in the American auto industry.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Mary M. Chapman

articles.headline: Emirates Secretly Sends Colombian Mercenaries to Yemen Fight
articles.snippet: The arrival in Yemen of 450 Latin American troops adds a volatile new element in a complex proxy war that has drawn in the United States and Iran.
articles.abstract: The arrival in Yemen of 450 Latin American troops adds a volatile new element in a complex proxy war that has drawn in the United States and Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United Arab Emirates has secretly dispatched hundreds of Colombian mercenaries to Yemen to fight in that country’s raging conflict, adding a volatile new element in a complex proxy war that has drawn in the United States and Iran.
articles.byline: By Emily B. Hager and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Koch Brothers Woo Hispanic Voters With Turkeys and Questionnaires
articles.snippet: Tapping some Democratic strategies, the Libre Initiative seeks to win over Hispanics by promoting economic freedom and smaller-government principles.
articles.abstract: Tapping some Democratic strategies, the Libre Initiative seeks to win over Hispanics by promoting economic freedom and smaller-government principles.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The crowd that lined up around a megachurch here last week — largely Hispanic and mostly poor — came for the Saturday services, but also for the free flu shots that were being offered in the church, and for the Thanksgiving turkeys being given away just outside.

articles.headline: Range of Frustrations Reached Boil as Turkey Shot Down Russian Jet
articles.snippet: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had nuanced reasons to allow Turkish pilots to open fire, analysts say, including his irritation with Russia over issues beyond Syria.
articles.abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had nuanced reasons to allow Turkish pilots to open fire, analysts say, including his irritation with Russia over issues beyond Syria.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey — Turkey and Russia promised on Wednesday not to go to war over the downing of a Russian military jet, leaving Turkey’s still-nervous NATO allies and just about everyone else wondering why the country decided to risk such a serious confrontation.

articles.headline: Small Shops Take Pride in Turning Their Backs on Black Friday
articles.snippet: Some independent retailers are choosing closed doors over doorbusters and even forgoing all holiday discounts, saying that doing so makes smart business sense.
articles.abstract: Some independent retailers are choosing closed doors over doorbusters and even forgoing all holiday discounts, saying that doing so makes smart business sense.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Black Friday, as hordes of people begin their holiday shopping rites, Nan Morningstar will keep the door closed at Free Radicals, the clothing and costume boutique she and her husband own in Albuquerque.

articles.headline: U.S. General Says Kunduz Hospital Strike Was ‘Avoidable’
articles.snippet: Several service members have been suspended after an internal military investigation of the American airstrike on a Doctors Without Borders facility in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Several service members have been suspended after an internal military investigation of the American airstrike on a Doctors Without Borders facility in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The top American commander in Afghanistan, Gen. John F. Campbell, said Wednesday that several service members had been suspended from duty after an internal military investigation of the American airstrike on a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz last month.
